title: AB 624
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 11302 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to appraisals in federally related transactions. The Department of Consumer Affairs is referred to as the "Department," and an "appraisal" is described as a written statement prepared by a qualified appraiser to determine the market value of a property. The term "appraisal" excludes opinions from real estate licensees, engineers, or land surveyors in their licensed functions. The Appraisal Foundation is defined as a not-for-profit corporation. An "appraisal management company" is any entity meeting specific conditions. An appraisal management company maintains a list of licensed appraisers, receives appraisal requests from clients, and delegates assignments for a fee. It does not include banks or financial institutions that contract directly with independent appraisers. An appraisal management company maintains a list of licensed appraisers, receives appraisal requests from clients, and delegates assignments for a fee. It excludes individuals licensed to practice law in California working on appraisals for their clients. The Appraisal Subcommittee refers to the Appraisal Subcommittee of the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council. A controlling person can be a finance lender, residential mortgage lender, real estate broker, or other authorized entities. A "controlling person" in an appraisal management company can be an officer, director, or individual with ownership interest. They have the authority to enter into contracts for appraisal services and direct the company's management. The "director" or "chief" refers to the Chief of the Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers. The "director" or "chief" refers to the Chief of the Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers. The "Federal financial institutions regulatory agency" includes various federal agencies with jurisdiction over transactions subject to this part. "Federally related real estate appraisal activity" involves making or performing an appraisal on real estate in a federally related transaction. The "Federally related transaction" refers to any real estate-related financial transaction regulated by a federal financial institutions regulatory agency that requires the services of a state licensed real estate appraiser. A "License" is any authorization issued by the Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers allowing a person to act within the state. "Licensure" pertains to the procedures and requirements for obtaining a license. The "Office" or "bureau" refers to the Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers. The Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers defines terms such as registration, state licensed real estate appraiser, Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice, course provider, and nonfederally related real estate appraisal activity. The Bureau of Real Estate Appraisers defines key terms related to real estate appraisal. The amended section of the Business and Professions Code establishes the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice as the minimum standard for real estate appraisal activities. Licensees must also follow standards set by the Board of Equalization for assessment purposes if certified by them. If a licensee is performing a nonfederally related appraisal activity, they can use a standard of valuation practice with client agreement and disclosure. If a different standard is used, the licensee must still comply with Ethics, Record Keeping, Competency, and Scope of Work rules of the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.
